Tell HN: My dad told me I'd be a high school dropout and I make 200k a year
text:
Before I start this.

I'm in therapy.

I am so grateful to all of you, to every programmer who helped me on stack overflow. To everyone on on the Unity forums, who would help me with extremely basic programming questions. When I first started programming, I had no direction. I didn't even understand what an array was. Now, despite my dad being a psychotic violent monster, I had actually gotten into a nice college after high School. I did go to community college first, and there. I met so many amazing great people.

One girl from high school who was actually extremely smart, she got into a really good school. But unfortunately she had to drop out of her for your school and go to a community, because her mom was demoted at work.

I will say from my time in college, and meeting people there's one policy. I hate with the most fervancy

And it's affirmative action by far, all of my Asian friends have lives which were way worse than mine. A Chinese friend was living in a homeless shelter at 19 because his dad was so f*** abusive. His dad would just beat him every single day

However, because my mother couldn't fill out a basic form. God bless her heart, I ended up dropping out.

But within about 3 years of dropping out of college I was already at 100k. By the time I applied for financial aid to finish up my last year of college, I didn't qualify for anything.

text: You bet on the direction of a crypto price in the next 60 secs (up/down). If you're right, you can win >60%, if you're wrong, you lose your investment. Onboard just with an ETH transfer, no KYC, no trading fees. Fun mode available.

Ask HN: Is Venture Capital becoming Vegas-style gambling machine?
text:
I was reading various stories on Softbank's poor performance for the last five years. It is back to zero in providing returns for its Vision fund. Other late stage funds are undergoing a similar fate where money poured. Without any checks.

There are other stories of how founders have schemed the investors. Raised at 100X revenue valuations. Spent millions of dollars. Without a product to show. Without customer traction.

I'm an idealist. Venture Capital is a greater good. It democratizes access to capital to people who otherwise did not inherit. But nervous that this tulip mania like cycle hurts more than helps.

Are people just playing roulette? Is high-tech no longer tech? But just high on the kool-aid of unabashed flow of money?

Ask HN: How to teach myself not to overcomplicate?
text:
All my personal projects seem to fail because I jump off the deep end.

E.g. I want to implement a simple image hosting to learn GCP and have some fun with React/Tailwind (I had AWS experience). Instead of building the hosting itself I start with user authentication, reading about Passport.js, JWT, specs, etc. I spend a lot of time on this, until I get bored and set the project aside...

I have 20+ years of experience and I worked on stuff like Node.js and Chromium - so I know a lot of "what can go wrong" in a cloud application - security, scalability. How can I learn to ignore those concerns when I toy with code for fun?
